sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Bronchospasm - Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: INHALE 1 puff (400 mcg) ORALLY twice daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy have not been established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• geriatric: no dose adjustment necessary
  • renal impairment: no dose adjustment necessary

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Immunologic:
  • -- Immediate hypersensitivity reactions have been reported; immediate discontinuation recommended
  • -- Patients with a history of hypersensitivity reactions to atropine; monitor closely for similar hypersensitivity reactions
  • -- Use caution in patients with severe hypersensitivity to milk proteins
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- Use caution in patients with narrow-angle glaucoma; worsening of condition may occur
  • Renal:
  • -- Use caution in patients with urinary retention; worsening of condition may occur
  • Respiratory
  • -- Paradoxical bronchospasm may occur; discontinue if occurs
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- Avoid use with other anticholinergic-containing drugs

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Neurologic:Headache (6.6%)
  • Respiratory:Cough (3%), Nasopharyngitis (5.5%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:First degree atrioventricular block (less than 1%), Heart failure (less than 1%)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Respiratory:Cardiorespiratory arrest (less than 1%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Aclidinium bromide is a long-acting antimuscarinic agent that inhibits the M(1) through M(5) receptors. Inhaled aclidinium bromide inhibits the M(3) receptor at the smooth muscle in the airways, leading to bronchodilation.

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal: 0.09% (inhalation); 54% to 65%, 1% unchanged (IV); 0.014% to 0.111% (renal impairment)
  • Fecal: 20% to 33%
  • Renal Clearance: 2.2 to 13.7 mL/min (renal impairment)
  • Total body clearance: 170 L/hr; 1745 to 3299 L/hr (renal impairment)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Inhalation
  • press and release green button and then make sure control window has changed from red to green before inhalation
  • breathe out completely before forming a tight seal with lips around mouthpiece and breathe in; there will be a clicking sound; control window should turn red after inhalation
  • discard after the dose indicator displays a 0, the device locks out, or 45 days after removing the inhaler from the sealed pouch

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in signs/symptoms of bronchospasm associated with COPD is indicative of efficacy
  • hypersensitivity reactions; in patients with prior hypersensitivity to atropine

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause headache, cough, or common cold-like symptoms.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of allergic reaction including rash, hives, or swelling of the mouth, face, lips, or tongue.
  • Tell patient to report new or worsening urinary retention including difficult, frequent, or painful urination.
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of glaucoma including new or worsening ocular pressure.
  • Instruct patient immediately report sudden shortness of breath following drug use.
  • Tell patient to immediately report exacerbation of breathing problems, increased use of a rescue inhaler, or if the rescue inhaler does not work as well at relieving symptoms.
  • Instruct patient to take drug twice daily approximately 12 hours apart.
  • Patient should avoid use of concomitant anticholinergics and/or atropine.
  • Instruct patient to skip a missed dose and resume treatment with the next scheduled dose. Do not take a double dose.
